Discipline Code faces first test
By CAROL TRZCINSKI
The appeals provision of the
newly instituted Discipline Code
was tested for the first time
yesterday as one of four
students linked with the fire set
last week in Lazear House
appealed Dean Robert J.
Fitzpatrick's disciplinary
decision.
Jason Brajer, who had
previously been handed a
decision from the Dean which
denied him use of the Dormitory
complex for the remainder of the
academic year, obtained a
relatively lighter sentence from
an'Ad Hoc Committee which had
been called to reconsider the
case.
According to their decision,
Brajer will be on disciplinary
probation for the remainder of
the semester. The provisions of
that status prohibit participation
in any extra-curricular activities
until this fall. Brajer must also
make restitution of damage
from the fire and smoke.
The Committee, in addition to
these specific moves, specifically
indicated to Brajer the condition
that "his behavior in the dorms
be of an extremely exemplary
nature" during the remainder of
his stay there.
Brajer, along with fellow
Lazear residents John Fung.
Fallon Maylock, and Eugen
Vuozzo, were charged with
starting a fire last Tuesday night
on the third floor of their dorm
by squirting lighter fluid under
the door of one of its residents'
room, and setting fires to it,
causing extensive fire and smoke
damage to the door.
The other three students chose
not to appeal their cases
yesterday, although they were
given last weekend/to consider
such action, thereby prolonging
the Friday noon deadline set by
Fitzpatrick last week.
All three students will sustain
Fitzpatrick's original sentence,
and two will furthermore be
suspended for two weeks.
Fitzpatrick's decision in this
instance on the time allowed for

a defendent to appeal his case
crosses the Code as written by
Student Council President
Andrew Savitz which includes no
such time factor associated with
the appeals process.
"I think Bob [Fitzpatrick]
used the Friday deadline as a
benchmark for making the
students consult their families
and come to a decision," stated
Director of Student Affairs
Dottie Lebo who testified at the
hearing yesterday.
"There's not an unequivocating
end of appeal, although that's a
problem with the Code as it
stands now."
Lebo, speaking on behalf of
the Dean who was out of town
this week, pointed out that the
expediency of making appeals
decision was necessary to insure
the accuracy of the testimonies.
Commenting on the execution
of the appeals provision Lebo
commented, "This was a real sign
that the appeals method was
working."

Savitz & Raab toss hats into ring
By MARK DUVIOSIN
The campaign for the office of
Student Council President was
officially begun last night when
SC President Andy Savitz and
Junior Class President Dan Raab
formally announced their
intentions to seek the office.
Savitz, who is seeking a third
term as president, indicated that
if reelected he would attempt to
deal with three broad problems:
tuition, housing, and academics.
Raab stated that he would
"revamp entirely the Student
Activities Commission."
"I'd like to expand the SAC
Executive Committee to a group
of five people and have it
ultimately report to the entire
SAC. The idea of having three
people distributing money is
wrong in priciple," Raab
asserted.
Savitz similarly indicated that
he would alter the present SAC

structure. "I may push to expand
the size of the Executive
Committee and to review the
SAC constitution," he said. "But
people don't realize that the SAC
Executive Committee does not
have the final say-so. Our budget
has to be approved by the
council at large," he added.
Both candidates expressed an
interest in expanding the range
and frequency of campus social
activities. "What the campus
lacks now is a place where people
can get together and talk, a
gathering place. I hope that the
Rathskellar in the Union will
become such a place," Savitz
said.
"The Junior class has been a
very active class in terms of the
parties and dances we've
sponsored," Raab asserted. "I
have no doubts that the quality
of the social life can be upgraded
next year," he added.

Both candidates presented
possible innovations for next
year's council structure. "I'd like
to see a student position
established as a sort of
ombudsman to Dr. Muller," Raab
indicated.
"This sort of position already
exists with regards to Dean
Suskind, and Dr. Benton and
would be especially significant
since the Hopkins Hundreds
campaign is coming up," he
added.
Savitz described a program
which the council has already
initiated. "We have established a
committee to review academic
departments and individual
professors with the emphasis on
non-tenured professors," he said.
"The results will eventually be
presented to the Academic
Council subcommittees. I think it
may have a substantial effect,"
he added.

Medical institutions may lose federal bucks
According to a recent report
on the relationship of Hopkins'
Medical Institutions to the
Federal Government, the
University may be forced to
consider alternate sources of
funding to replace federal
support in the future.
The report notes that a
substantial reduction has taken
place in the amount of
open-ended research funds, such
as training grants, available from
the federal government.
"Open ended, loosely
controlled reserach supported by
traditional individual research
grants and General Research
Support Grant programs have

lost ground to support modes
more closely controlled by NIH,
such as contracts and targeted
centers."
The document was prepared
for a two-day-long strategy
session on Hopkins' medical
Institutions held early this month
at Evergreen House.
Although the report notes that
on the national level federal
funding for scientific reserach has
been falling, Hopkins has
increased its level of support
from Federal sources both in
terms of current dollars and in
terms of 1968 dollars, indicating
that the funding level has more
than made up for the inflation

that has taken place.
The School of Hygiene and the
Medical School are about 75
percent and 50 percent funded
by the federal government. From
training grants, Hygiene got $3.5
million and Medicine $4 million.
These grants would be
terminated completely under a
policy change recommended by
the Office of Management and
Budget.

misused

Disciplinary proceedings are nearly always an inherently
distasteful matter, but it appears that the first test of
Homewood's new discipline plan was a successful one. One of
the students involved in last week's fire setting incident in
Lazear House chose to appeal the decision made in the
matter by Dean of Students Robert J. Fitzpatrick and
succeeded in having punishment reduced considerable.
Once the student decided to appeal his case, an appeals
board was constituted, the case was heard and a decision was
quickly reached and so the discipline plan worked out over
months of wrangling false starts and dispute appears to be a
success in all respects except one. The major point of
contention comes over the fact that asit now stands the
question of how long a student has to file an appeal remains
open. This is a dangerous flaw. If a student were to delay for
as long as a year his decision to take his case to an appeals
board, memories could fade and some of the people
involved could leave the University, rendering the entire
appeals process a dangerous absurdity.
While it is certainly to be hoped that no more incidents of
the type that occurred in Lazear House last week will occur
in the future, the discipline procedure should still be equal to
the test of possible future appeals The only way that the
future viability of the plan can be assured is for a time limit
to be instituted on appealing. Otherwise a student could
make a mockery of the entire process by waiting for
memories to become dim, for persons involved in the
incident to leave Hopkins and for possible evidence—a
charred door for example—to disappear. It should certainly
not be difficult for the Student Council and the Homewood
Advisory Council to work out an acceptable provision on the
time limit question. Both groups should start to do so
quickly.

Disciplinary proceedings are nearly always an inherently
distasteful matter, but it appears that the first test of
Homewood's new discipline plan was a successful one. One of
the students involved in last week's fire setting incident in
Lazear House chose to appeal the decision made in the
matter by Dean of Students Robert J. Fitzpatrick and
succeeded in having punishment reduced considerable.
Once the student decided to appeal his case, an appeals
board was constituted, the case was heard and a decision was
quickly reached and so the discipline plan worked out over
months of wrangling false starts and dispute appears to be a
success in all respects except one. The major point of
contention comes over the fact that asit now stands the
question of how long a student has to file an appeal remains
open. This is a dangerous flaw. If a student were to delay for
as long as a year his decision to take his case to an appeals
board, memories could fade and some of the people
involved could leave the University, rendering the entire
appeals process a dangerous absurdity.
While it is certainly to be hoped that no more incidents of
the type that occurred in Lazear House last week will occur
in the future, the discipline procedure should still be equal to
the test of possible future appeals The only way that the
future viability of the plan can be assured is for a time limit
to be instituted on appealing. Otherwise a student could
make a mockery of the entire process by waiting for
memories to become dim, for persons involved in the
incident to leave Hopkins and for possible evidence—a
charred door for example—to disappear. It should certainly
not be difficult for the Student Council and the Homewood
Advisory Council to work out an acceptable provision on the
time limit question. Both groups should start to do so
quickly.
